document.title: WJEC GCSE in Digital Technology Specification

D2394D17BECE4626A420735934BF74C6.description:
Learners should understand success criteria for marketing
campaigns in terms of the following:
• goals of the company
• goals for the marketing campaign
• target demographic
• branding
• goals for the standard of the digital asset.

A52527D7E1E440C584104F0E86BE68A2.description:
Learners should understand that digital media assets and
copy need to be assessed for:
• suitability of purpose
• suitability for target audience/demographic
• consistency of house style.

7D7F20403F984A838DB2211B20650BC7.description:
Developing
coherence between
digital media assets
and copy

B6AC5E43A2154FF99988CDF24E85B568.description:
Learners should be able to determine a social media
marketing communications strategy using the following:
• user-led content
• user-led stories
• pre-video ads
• social media tags.

123C75B094C74AFA873179515735EEC1.description:
Determining online
digital marketing
communications
strategy

0A111C6B0E3345BCA6E7A93A466CEBC2.description:
Learners should understand the importance of:
• identifying customer needs and wants
• evaluating demand
• identifying quantifiable objectives.

F59AEBB570D54341966FFC6D2743113C.description:
Learners should be able to evaluate the extent to which a
digital media asset supports a digital communications
strategy.

1BE4AB33FBAA46ACA974DDFD4DE6F052.description:
Learners should be able to use appropriate software or apps to create digital media assets. This should include the following: export of digital media assets to another specified
format.

502FA0D335014BBA992DEC5E2CF28BFA.description:
Learners should be able to use appropriate software or apps to create digital media assets. This should include the following: moving images
• creation of an asset
• insertion into another asset
• manipulation of assets

1907898318B7407A84FDE4622D732C30.description:
Learners should be able to use appropriate software or apps to create digital media assets. This should include the following: graphics/images/photographs
• creation of an asset
• insertion into another asset
• manipulation of assets

2AAAC2677277438D97ABCA1CCB6B552D.description:
Learners should be able to use appropriate software or apps
to create digital media assets. This should include the
following:
• copy (text)
• inputting text
• manipulating text

0E5AD116EC674B15BD6570A9D453F70A.description:
Using appropriate
software or apps to
create digital media
assets to support
digital
communications
strategies, in these
forms:
• copy (text)
• photographs,
images, graphics
and manipulated
images
• edited live-action
moving images

BC90489ED9104EE39E60CD429B7E3F61.description:
Learners should understand the following risks associated
with online marketing communications:
• credibility
• cyber security risks
• dependent on technology
• higher transparency of prices
• maintenance costs due to technological advances
• security/privacy
• trending and viral uptake
• worldwide competition.

953C123BB5FA4273A954AC6B96785860.description:
Learners should understand the following benefits and
opportunities of online marketing communications:
• market penetration – sell more into existing markets
• market development – new geographical markets
• brand building – brand awareness, familiarity,
favourability
• interaction – trigger based, event driven.

9B1EE2F1C5AB425087DF4AAC81019EA3.description:
Learners should understand that digital marketing targeting
may be achieved using:
• automated promotions
• demographics.

EB7BB3F0504E43A8BA7353886A212E7E.description:
Learners should understand the importance of digital
marketing coherence including:
• planning the content
• writing the content
• reviewing the content.

F5D21ACE5A5345BBA691E7F12BA5A826.description:
Learners should understand that digital marketing
placement may involve the use of:
• social networking sites
• microblogging
• photo sharing
• video sharing.

4898709523FD4FB2B40CD2EB1D2C09D1.description:
Learners should be aware of the following forms of digital
marketing including generic elements such as:
• logos
• taglines
• edited sequences
• colour effects.

9436188C74254EB9B761479C91ACE71A.description:
Online digital
marketing:
• forms
• placement
• coherence
• targeting

168CE3722E6D4E27BF4EE4C6C1100428.description:
Learners should be aware of the features of social media
platforms including:
• individualising profiles
• expanding user following
• privacy and security
• notifications
• newsfeed
• integration with other social media platforms
• comments/reviews
• bookmarking/saving
• posts
• media
• sharing.

A6FAA9B0705841D5BFA9D0754F0D4AE7.description:
Learners should be aware of the characteristics of different
social media platforms and what they allow users to do in
terms of:
• profiles
• connections
• uploading content in real time
• enabling comments/conversations
• time stamped posts.

DF09295446754B3CB65FBE80EC75760E.description:
Learners should be aware of the importance of considering
the typical demographics of social media platforms, in terms
of the protected characteristics under the Equality Act 2010
(age, disability, gender reassignment, pregnancy and
maternity, race, religion or belief, sex and sexual orientation,
marriage and civil partnership) when deciding on which
media to use in communications campaigns.

8BD7FCB3D1614185BD70C4B77F7C5A08.description:
Social media
platforms:
• demographics
• characteristics
• features

219008D6273244C792D660830AF0A677.description:
Learners should be able to use data gathering techniques
such as: surveys, interviews and observation to obtain target
audience feedback and evaluate the extent to which the final
product meets the identified needs.

F0216E5B271F4D70BA3C073D7B874ABA.description:
Evaluating the
extent to which data-informed
digital
products satisfy the
identified needs,
trends or audiences

72626B43D497401084F8D8FC25A14AF7.description:
Learners should be able to design, implement and document
tests to remove errors and bugs.

D062AC3CF41A49B795159A226E5D6A4D.description:
Testing completed
digital products to
remove errors/bugs

F8EC2A29F0CB43478F0D30E75B06F6B3.description:
Learners should be able to document issues, problems and
hurdles as well as describing their solutions by maintaining
an up to date:
• development log
• assets log.

64BF6D21156C40F29D347FEC575741E0.description:
Logging:
• issues, problems
and hurdles
• solutions

388A4FB447464F14BF538A86923EF6FD.description:
Learners should understand the importance of reviewing
work and making changes based on feedback.

04DB93D1473F4A5BAD3DEB879868EDB4.description:
Develop digital
products that meets
identified needs,
trends or audiences

574435DA047C4B31B26E7B729A0943AF.description:
either use game development software to create games
with several layers
• or use animation software to create animations that
contain a number of scenes.

867F59A015494594AC3E494C80E2B231.description:
use web authoring software to create structured web
pages

8D9D6461E46440B7803C9B4B065328D9.description:
In order to support the development of digital products
learners should, using a variety of appropriate techniques
be able to:
• use image software to create and manipulate images,
considering copyright

549027797C404160BB95E0843FF425CC.description:
Learners should understand the importance of producing a
documented prototype that can be reviewed and tested.

E6DC4A6A1B894FAB875F496F387E7E38.description:
Develop and use
appropriate
technical skills to
develop digital
products

0C4C7EC07FCC43D49ABE169D1336A658.description:
Learners should understand the importance of creating and
maintaining up to date development logs to document the
elements of planning, development and evaluation.

92B1BC998BCE41ABBC259060F48790BF.description:
Learners should understand the importance of incorporating
accessibility features into relevant aspects of their digital
products.

DC5FDDBB9B0445B3B099596257B7F12F.description:
Learners should understand the importance of using a
storyboard/template when designing websites, games and
animations to ensure consistency in terms of structure and
appearance.

1DC7426248E44AB1ACD2B77224FAFCF9.description:
Planning technical
aspects of designs
(including resource
aspects, visual
aspects, sound
aspects, etc.)

12DEF8DCDBE14861AECA135A699D96A5.description:
Learners should be able to:
• use tools such as sketching or wireframes to establish
design solutions
• evaluate design solutions to select a design based on
target audience feedback and needs
• collect evidence in a development log.

A309D975D7D5436B9E632AA90D9EE22E.description:
Leaners should be able to use data analysis to identify:
• a target audience
• audience requirements.

CDC42FCD6F0D4D848F933532F647FFF2.description:
Proposing digital
products to satisfy
trends, needs or
audiences

83AE5ED32AC642FBBDA937BC1B79B85A.description:
Learners should be able to:
• use different forms of data analysis to identify trends and
patterns to establish audience needs.
• carry out what-if analyses.

56B47175DB444AE0A0E0176BE034DE5A.description:
Learners should be able to use data visualisation features
within spreadsheet software to present data in the most
appropriate format.

92BAD74D7F2E493688F9D96F5B754E5E.description:
Learners should be able to use a variety of descriptive
analysis functions and features within spreadsheet software
to summarise data.

00536F28824F472EA676247A1F7C19A9.description:
Learners should understand that:
• descriptive data analytics can provide useful information
• this is achieved by carrying out descriptive analysis and
data visualisation.

E53169F8E6A6427BBE7AE28B2EEB14C0.description:
Descriptive data
analytics: statistics
and visualisation

71E2A0B29F2943D4A94ED4E53EF81322.description:
Learners should be able to appropriately use searching,
sorting and filtering within spreadsheet software.

88832C3CFEF04F5393C46FFD6820B59F.description:
use features within spreadsheet software to cleanse and
organise data by:
• sorting data
• removing duplicates
• removing superfluous characters
• using a variety of string functions
• rounding numbers up or down to a particular number
of decimal places.

3BC79A7B5E594596870D76E09EF74CC8.description:
Learners should be able to:
• use manual methods and computer programs to cleanse
data in order to:
• remove duplicates
• remove inaccurate data
• save storage space

C33C626FE70A45CEB762346FC80B5BC3.description:
Learners should be aware that it is sometimes necessary to
cleanse data and organise data.

3542BAF159D44118BB65205877F01AEF.description:
Learners should be aware that data can be obtained from
many different sources and presented in different formats.
Learners should be able to:
• import text files into a new or existing spreadsheet
• format data to appropriate data types.

F61DE34C98F34843B25EC62C5BF76016.description:
Learners should be able to:
• identify and use a range of data types in a spreadsheet
• select the most appropriate data types to use from the
raw data presented to them.

824FC3DD14DB42E999FEB6E558D3E67A.description:
Types of data and
their characteristics

A76EE28F4582463896EC3560BC0EF02F.description:
Learners should be aware of the main impacts on society,
the economy and culture that new and emerging
technology, trends and future developments and drivers in
the digital technology world may have.

F90F230C34D94B58A1C9DA33A60C9B30.description:
Noteworthy research
on new and
emerging trends,
future developments
and drivers

A12155C067604C0CAAA5EF59AF989D9E.description:
Learners should be aware of the main impacts on society,
the economy and culture of the following developments in
digital technology that have evolved over time:
• industrial robots
• autonomous robots
• autonomous vehicles
• virtual reality
• augmented reality
• Artificial Intelligence (AI)
• machine learning
• internet-enabled hardware including the Internet of
Things (IOT).

418FBDFE93F54EF1919731BE10448BDD.description:
The evolution of:
• industrial and
autonomous
robotics
• autonomous
vehicles
• virtual and
augmented reality
• artificial
intelligence and
machine learning
• internet-enabled
hardware

8CDEEF3CA2514D319D8DC659E77A40DB.description:
Sir Tim Berners-Lee.
• inventor of the World Wide Web.

22FCBD80AC544112B87421C9C396ADCE.description:
Steve Jobs
• commoditised computing, and developed
smartphones and hand-held devices

BD7F0F5B113A4598A2A43F6A35D3067C.description:
Alan Turing
• developed computational theory upon which modern
computing is based

D4C16B8279554CFBA2C1F2BC61C83745.description:
Admiral Grace Hopper
• devised the first commercial electronic computer

46BA64BBC2F943B284D57FC3C35D698F.description:
James Gosling
• developed the Java programming language

F708DEDA9EAE49C8BA2C44DDCE4E8BA5.description:
Lady Ada Lovelace
• the first computer programmer, the first person to
realise computers could do more than just calculate
numbers

52F871359212403ABF5CCE08AF8E6369.description:
Key milestones,
including the
contributions of
individuals, in the
development of
communications,
computing systems
and digital devices. Learners should be aware of the following individuals and
their key contribution to IT:

45E9AEDA78A34985887A2E2BDE54C5D5.description:
Learners should be aware of the ethical impact of the
widescale use of data and systems on:
• individual privacy
• wider society.

82318C01719E45D48484F1379DBA5F19.description:
Learners should be aware of the basic principles and what
constitutes a breach of the following legislation relating to
the use of computers, data and electronic communications
and their impact on privacy and trust:
• The Data Protection Act 2018 including the General
Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
• The Computer Misuse Act 1990
• The Investigatory Powers Act 2016.

9E441F1D4A0C49918CF5865387D369C4.description:
Legal and ethical
responsibilities,
including:
• privacy
• trust

537C38F9466D4FCFAD296C11B46B6BD8.description:
Learners should be aware of the potential impact of a digital
footprint being used by:
• employers to monitor employees or potential employees
• security services to gather information
• applications to target potential customers.

6741C3983C604CFD98816BEE24A05D32.description:
Learners should understand the term digital footprint and
that the following are different types of digital footprint:
• a passive digital footprint – data collected without a
user’s knowledge
• an active digital footprint – data intentionally submitted
online via blogs, apps, websites and social media
actions.

2777B10B76494E90B866AC2C024067A7.description:
the following resilience controls a company could use to
recover from a cyber attack:
• having arrangements for the use of alternative
premises, communication methods and facilities
• exploring various what-if scenarios
• ensuring regular backups of data.

CA21C14BE2054BF8B53CCE497F071D18.description:
the following resilience controls a company may use to
prevent a cyber attack:
• using a boundary firewall and internet gateway
• having secure system configuration including admin
accounts, audit trails, account management and
backup
• implementing access control including restricted
access to valuable data
• implementing malware protection
• having patch management to ensure the latest
updates of software are applied to all machines
• ensuring known vulnerabilities are dealt with and the
latest version of an application is being used
• implementing staff training to ensure staff are not
putting data at risk.

135C026C5FD3499891FCCF858B005970.description:
Learners should understand: the potential consequences to a company of a cyber
attack:
• temporary or permanent loss of data and information
• damaged or corrupted software
• websites taken down
• loss of reputation
• loss of competitive advantage
• financial loss.

407DABAA386D406CB4B107036E717956.description:
Learners should understand:
• cyber resilience as being a company’s ability to prepare,
survive, respond to and recover from a cyber attack

7AC2A768D7FF48F1B54D7D55832B9A5D.description:
The range of cyber
security resilience
controls

F8926D63CBAC4A81A1FB85AB5F36CA9D.description:
how networks, systems, transmitted and stored data can
be protected using the following security measures:
• encryption
• firewalls
• antivirus software
• hierarchical access levels.

7DD1F706615C4AE387370870207C22EF.description:
Learners should understand:
• the following threats to data stored on computer systems
and online:
• accidental damage – identifying how data can be at
risk from accidental destruction
• malicious and deliberate damage

CA714AE360404A4DB2BADC18F7B59BBF.description:
The range of threats
to data

D13979C5802C40B59D8ABB026B612DE8.description:
Learners should be aware of:
• marketing to prospective and existing customer by email,
social media or other means
• advertising through websites
• data mining and analytics.

75608FFC9E9E4BDFAFCF20E17C45DDB5.description:
Rise of services and
monetising content

C8CAC1E4E3834FA387E015EEC86AF69A.description:
Learners should be aware of the advantages and
disadvantages to both customers and businesses of:
• Business to Business (B2B) Electronic Data Interchange
(EDI)
• online shopping
• online marketplaces which process 3rd party Business to
Consumer (B2C) or Consumer to Consumer (C2C)
sales.
• B2B buying and selling.

3C571DA6677142CBA88774F1DA4EF8F4.description:
Changing
relationships
between producers,
manufacturers,
distributers and
consumers

490077725CB9474197CECD783D50FB7D.description:
Learners should be aware of the impact that changing
working practices have had on culture and society.

EDE4F00B230D48D8B9B90C32DC4AD9E4.description:
Learners should understand the following methodologies for
implementing digital systems:
• pilot method
• parallel method
• ‘big bang’ method.

C6D4C3C6F3B24BFC8990BC69D88EC34F.description:
Learners should be aware of the efficiencies and benefits of
digital systems and be able to identify benefits and
drawbacks of:
• office based digital systems for an organisation
• consumer digital systems for an individual.

7BEEF5D9374A41FD9326C290788FAFA9.description:
Efficiencies and
benefits provided by
digital systems

02B6508BC54A46E9AD7E12BB12A9B5B5.description: Impact of digital systems on organisations and individuals

52CB8277968E49E0A79E5242CFF9D934.description:
Learners should understand:
• how contemporary social networking platforms work
• the benefits and drawbacks of social media
• how social networking affects the concept of ownership
of media.

A6F90777EDF7420CB94D8C6E46D830BF.description:
the following methods that verify information found
online:
• checking multiple sources
• using trustworthy websites.

066A4BD87CD745DFB5E8455DF32B8144.description:
Learners should understand:
• the issues around the reliability of online sources and
facts in relation to:
• accuracy of information
• biased information
• out of date information

C7B7B14984FF40AA83510724874501DF.description:
the following internal and external business
communication methods:
• video conferencing
• teleworking
• emailing
• promotion methods – advertising, marketing,
websites
• apps.

253B363E62284F1A9E2D86666F95181A.description:
the following types of personal and social
communication methods, including the social norms and
expected behaviour when using them:
• emailing
• instant messaging
• blogs
• video conferencing
• social networking websites and apps

2B36D4D7B813464BB600C2FADFECEFC1.description:
Learners should be aware of:
• a range of digital communication methods, their
advantages and disadvantages and any associated
barriers to communication

3EAAF51816994C05B314C68FBCDA4ECB.description:
Range of digital
communication
methods for
personal, social and
business uses

63385261A6764751B22987D179E16CBE.description:
Learners should understand the six parts of the systems
development life cycle:
• System Investigation
• System Analysis
• System Design
• System Implementation
• System Maintenance
• System Evaluation.

07668E59C1294F5AA37FB117071403D1.description:
Learners should be able to describe cloud services and
understand: • the advantages and disadvantages of using cloud
services.

2436320DC38E4777B0FD5979584895B1.description:
Learners should be able to describe cloud services and
understand:
• the difference between cloud computing and cloud
storage

5A61581E0E284355813437F6BC15FB68.description:
understand the need for a disaster recovery plan and
be able to explain suitable options for recovery.

022BA5A12DC54C51A31B6CC81611F8BE.description:
be able to describe the following media used for
backing up data and their suitability in different
circumstances:
• Universal Serial Bus (USB) flash drive
• external hard drive
• solid state media
• cloud storage

6C5AC5F6CC194B2ABB9525D9227B4EBE.description:
Learners should:
• understand the importance of backing data up and be
able to describe the following processes:
• full backup
• incremental backup
• differential backup
• Grandfather - Father - Son (GFS) methodology

1E59D42DD3464D61A09146E6D4926995.description:
understand the use and purpose of the following utility
applications:
• task scheduling
• antivirus software and functions.

A1BCA256FA36492EA536922F13CCD92F.description:
Learners should:
• be aware of the following different types of software and
their purposes:
• applications software
• bespoke software written for specific purposes
• process control

CE46A5E7660D43D48FB9AB093F967B9B.description:
understand the uses, advantages and disadvantages of
using the following Human Computer Interfaces (HCIs)
• Command Line Interface (CLI)
• Graphical User Interface (GUI)
• Touch Sensitive Interface (TSI)
• menu driven interface
• biometrics
• voice driven interface.

18E57BBA1DAC43A58318CF33A493108A.description:
be able to describe the following features of an operating
system:
• managing resources
• managing peripherals including input and output
devices
• spooling
• managing memory
• managing processes
• managing security
• providing a user interface.

2FE1C521BA8B428FBD09DE41F9E6460A.description:
Learners should:
• understand the purpose and function of an operating
system

129C940ACFD44699A5855B4E4A4BE49E.description:
Learners should be aware of the following connection
methods for internet enabled devices, and the advantages
and disadvantages associated with each:
• broadband
• satellite
• fibre
• mobile communication – 4G/5G
• Wi-Fi – 802.11
• Bluetooth
• Geographical Information Systems (GIS).

2B9C5D0F94424258A2AE8DD6870A9A8A.description:
Learners should understand:
• that the Internet is a global communications network
which uses interconnected computers
• the infrastructure of the Internet includes clients, servers
and routers
• what an Internet Service Provider (ISP) is and the role it
plays
• how a search engine works
• that the World Wide Web (WWW) is a collection of
information held on the Internet
• how a web server works
• the role and structure of Uniform Resource Locators
(URL)
• how internet browsers request and display websites.

698E74CB9B9D4D47A44E7996B30D445C.description:
Learners should understand the following ways in which
users may interact with digital devices:
• speech
• traditional keyboard/mouse
• gesture
• touch
• Virtual Reality (VR)
• Augmented Reality (AR)
• biometrics.

A39CC47885904A6D8ADE58A666C97C52.description:
Digital devices and
means of:
• interaction
• connection

C622AD7A85F54062A179C5AB7978619F.description:
understand and identify the following storage mediums
and their application:
• magnetic
• optical
• cloud
• solid state.

0C19AFB42A3549E38B794852582A3106.description:
be able to describe the relationship between binary data
storage units

93BA7FB988B9479E95C7CF02A9915BC6.description:
understand that computer systems can only store and
process binary digits

852BA924F9CE4DC5A6422EC61EDE93BD.description:
demonstrate knowledge and understanding of how
images are stored digitally in terms of:
• pixels
• resolution
• vector and bitmap graphics
• moving image files
• compression techniques.

3E1253F83B0E4F0AB67D8CE257055164.description:
understand the advantages and disadvantages of
storing data digitally, in relation to the following:
• data retrieval
• efficiency
• security
• accessibility
• scalability
• loss of quality due to sampling
• expense
• management

B3EADC49335E4016B6F7E29CD1A8B72D.description:
Learners should:
• be able to explain the main principles of analogue to
digital conversion in relation to recording, sampling and
storing sound and light.

12EF0CAD87D747AE9C5723C9CC5CE87B.description:
Learners should understand:
• what is meant by analogue data
• what is meant by digital data
• analogue and digital devices
• the relationship between analogue and digital data.
